content:
Trainer Certification Card (â˜…â˜…) - Grand Party 1999-2000About #The Trainer Certification Card is a highly sought-after promotional PokÃ©mon TCG card from the early days of the franchise. It’s commonly referred to as the “Grand Party” card due to the prominent “Grand Party” text featured in its artwork and due to its release being tied to the Grand Party 1999-2000 campaign, a series of tournaments & events. There is an excellent write up on Pokumon.com about the Grand Party tournament circuit here
To get the card, players received a “challenge passport” which they had to log details of 50 battles, Once verified, they could claim the card as proof of their dedication, earning the title of “Official PokÃ©mon Card Certified Trainer.”
After filling out their passport with 50 battles and receiving the card, holders were entered into a lottery for invites to the exclusive Champion Road 2000 tournament.
This card and the Grand Party events were documented in early magazines and books such as “The Silver Bible” (PokÃ©mon Card Official Book 2000), a comprehensive Japanese guidebook published by Media Factory in 2000 dedicated to the PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game. It’s revered among collectors as an essential resource for early Japanese TCG history, often called a “sacred text” due to its detailed cataloging of cards that were obscure or exclusive to Japan at the time.
Below is a scan of the page featuring the Grand Party Trainer documented in “The Silver Bible” alongside a Translated copy by me.

content:
On July 7th, 2025, a user on the EliteFourum posted images of four Chinese Pokemon cards. The community quickly raised concerns about their authenticity and asked where the cards came from, as one of them was from a set that was not expected to be released for another three months.
The user responded:
“These were a gift from a client in China I met with last week â€” along with a giant stack of Espeon Masterballs.”
They also posted a photo showing a wider range of cards.
Community members pointed out that the samples did not appear to have the embossed PokÃ©mon logo in the bottom-left border â€” a common telltale sign of counterfeit cards.
The user reiterated:
Itâ€™s a printing sample. Itâ€™s not an officially released product.
Itâ€™s just a printing sample from a machine that makes cards.
They also provided additional photos from their supplier, including comparisons between known fakes and the samples in question.
One day later, on July 9th, 2025, TPC China announced that there had indeed been a leak of the new set from one of their partners, and that an investigation was underway.
Dear PokÃ©mon Trainer:
Thank you very much for your long-term support and trust in us! We noticed remarks about the stream of Simplified Chinese PokÃ©mon cards that have not yet been officially released on the web. Based on our companyâ€™s recent investigation into the incident, it has been confirmed that these unsold cards were leaked by one of our companyâ€™s partners, and the outflow process has been determined. At the moment, the incident is being processed further. Trainers are kindly requested to view online speech rationally and not to credulously and spread false and false information. We will strengthen security management in the future to avoid a recurrence of similar problems. PokÃ©mon (Shanghai) Toys Co, Ltd July 9, 2025
The user had offered free Espeon Masterballs to anyone interested. I reached out and requested one myself to take a closer look.
Upon receiving the cards, I inspected them using various methods to assess their authenticity. In every test, they appeared to be genuine.
They did in fact have the embossed logo too, though it is tricky to capture on camera.
The same user shared some additional information about the supplier of the cards, stating:
the supplier said they were made in January of 2024 from a supplier who lost their contract. Same digital assets and Iâ€™m assuming same printing methods but different material but with the same manufacturing standards.
They also made claims about a network of former licensed suppliers allegedly producing near-indistinguishable counterfeit products.
The post also takes a broader swipe at China’s intellectual property enforcement, claiming that local authorities are unlikely to intervene due to economic or political disinterest.
While the claims echo long-standing concerns in the trading card world about counterfeiting and overseas production, the lack of substantiated proof leaves many questions unanswered.
Currently, the cards are stored in my binder. I plan to print out a QR code linking to this webpage and place it alongside them, so I can revisit the information later.
I will update this post when i have done further research or any new information comes out.
I felt it was important to document and archive this information, both for my own future research and for anyone else who might be interested.
I would usually archive pages of importance with The Internet Archive, however in my experience it does not work as intended when archiving the EliteFourum.
title: PokÃ©mon 151C Chinese Leak & Espeon Sample Cards

__â€™s Kyogre (019/PLAY) - 3rd Season SubAbout #This card was awarded to players who subscribed to the third season of the Pokemon Players Club (PCGP) in Japan 2005. All subscribers received a sealed pack of 9 cards, 6 of the cards were from the previous seasons subscription (Celebi 012/PLAY, Mew 013/PLAY, Jirachi 014/PLAY, Cyclone Energy 015/PLAY, Boost Energy 016/PLAY, Warp Energy 017/PLAY) and 3 new ones for the third season (Kyogre 019/PLAY, Groudon 020/PLAY, Rayquaza 021/PLAY).
The PCGP is the successor to the original Pokemon Fan Club, recruitment for the PCGP began on January 31st, 2003. By signing up and paying the membership fee you receive a Players Kit and an ID. Inside the players kit is where you would receive the promo cards along with other items, your ID would store your EXP for the event. You could earn EXP through participating in Pokemon Card Events or competing in battles. Once you had enough EXP points you would receive more exclusive promo cards.

content:
Dusknoir (094/DP-P) - Spring Battle RoadAbout #This card was originally given to players who participated in the 2008 Spring Battle Road tournament in Japan. The tournament was supposed to be held across 5 different locations in Japan, however only 2 tournaments concluded before a bomb threat caused the remaining 3 to be canceled completely.
The official cancellation notice from pokemon reads:
The Kanto tournament (scheduled to be held on April 12th and 13th) of the “PokÃ©mon Card Game Battle Road Spring â˜…2008” was originally scheduled to be held from Sunday, March 23rd, 2008 at five venues nationwide for a total of seven days. Regarding I received a letter from an unknown sender stating that it would interfere with the holding of the tournament.
In response to this situation, after careful discussions with the relevant facilities, we have decided that the safety of our customers is our top priority, and we apologize for the inconvenience, but we have decided to cancel the Kanto tournament and the Chubu and Kyushu tournaments scheduled for the following. We have decided to do so. We apologize for the inconvenience, but we ask for your understanding as we are unable to provide details in order to avoid interfering with the investigation.
We sincerely apologize to our customers who have been looking forward to participating in this tournament for unexpectedly ending up in this situation.
Due to the cancellation, all members that had signed up to the Pokemon Daisuki Club were mailed a sealed promo pack containing this Dusknoir card as well as a Magnezone (093/DP-P) and also a Pikachu (095/DP-P).
Of the PokÃ©mon cards that we had planned to give away to visitors, we will be giving away a total of three (one each for Jibacoil, Yonoir, and Pikachu) by June 2, 2008 (Monday). Apply for a PokÃ©mon Daisuki Club card at the official PokÃ©mon fan club PokÃ©mon Daisuki Club. We have decided to send it to all customers who have applied for an annual membership fee.
In November of the same year, participants of the Challenge plaza tournament were also given 1 of 3 promo cards - This Dusknoir, a Pikachu (025/DP-P) & a Gible (026/DP-P) likely because of the bomb threat that cancelled some of the Battle Road tournaments.

Buneary (115/DP-P) - 2008 Collection Challenge : DP Exchange Japanese PromoAbout #The Collection Challenge: DP Exchange Card event was a promotional campaign held in Japan from Saturday 2 August ï½ Sunday 31 August 2008 at card game stores nationwide. PokÃ©mon fans were encouraged to bring 2 holofoil cards and trade them in return for a sealed pack containing the Buneary (115/DP-P) and Lopunny (116/DP-P) cards.
The event had guidelines such as:
“Replace with 2 PokÃ©mon Kira cards.” (Kira = Shiny) “Trainer cards and energy cards cannot be exchanged.” “The quanity of each card is limited.” “The card will end as soon as it runs out.” “One gift per person (one each).” Sealed pack of Buneary (115/DP-P) and Lopunny(116/DP-P)This particular event was a part of a larger event “Collection Challenge” beginning July 4th 2008 in which;
“you can get original cards from various locations across the country. Participate in events and campaigns held at PokÃ©mon movie theaters, PokÃ©mon card game stores, etc. nationwide, collect various cards, and enjoy your collection to the fullest! The PokÃ©mon differ depending on where you get the card, and the illustrations and moves are original to the PokÃ©mon card game “Collection Challenge”, so it’s truly a valuable card that can only be obtained here!!”

Houndour 050/L-P Reviving Legends PrizeAbout #This Houndour card was a participation prize for the Reviving Legends Release Commemoration Tournament held at a Challenge Plaza event in Febuary 2010, in Japan.
Players would compete in single-elimination matches, with a total of 5 rounds. Each participant would receive either a Scyther or Houndour card. The promo cards were distributed randomly, with each player receiving only one.
The cards were cosmos holofoil variants & featured the setâ€™s logo stamped on the card. On the Houndour the set stamp was in the bottom right corner of the artwork, with the PokÃ©mon logo and the text “Legend” in the top left corner. For the Scyther, it was the opposite with the logo in to the top right and set stamp in the bottom left.

Pikachu (4) - First Move Black Star Promo - Signed by Veronica Taylor, Voice of Ash KetchumAbout #Veronica TaylorVeronica Taylor is best known for her dubbing work in English-language adaptations of Japanese anime, in particular for voicing Ash Ketchum and his mother Delia in the PokÃ©mon anime for its first eight seasons.
The Pikachu (4) Promo card was give as one of four possible Wizards Black Star Promos that people could receive with the purchase of a ticket for the theatrical release of PokÃ©mon: The First Movie (Mewtwo Strikes Back) starting November 12, 1999.
Pikachu Promo CardThis particular signed Pikachu connects to Veronica Taylor through her role as Ash Ketchum in PokÃ©mon: The First Movie, her attendance at the LA premiere, and the cardâ€™s status as a promotional item tied to the film. The signature personalizes this collectible, linking her voice acting legacy to a key moment in PokÃ©monâ€™s history.

Lopunny (116/DP-P) - 2008 Collection Challenge : DP Exchange Japanese PromoAbout #The Collection Challenge: DP Exchange Card event was a promotional campaign held in Japan from Saturday 2 August ï½ Sunday 31 August 2008 at card game stores nationwide. PokÃ©mon fans were encouraged to bring 2 holofoil cards and trade them in return for a sealed pack containing the Buneary (115/DP-P) and Lopunny (116/DP-P) cards.
The event had guidelines such as:
“Replace with 2 PokÃ©mon Kira cards.” (Kira = Shiny) “Trainer cards and energy cards cannot be exchanged.” “The quanity of each card is limited.” “The card will end as soon as it runs out.” “One gift per person (one each).” Sealed pack of Buneary (115/DP-P) and Lopunny(116/DP-P)This particular event was a part of a larger event “Collection Challenge” beginning July 4th 2008 in which;
“you can get original cards from various locations across the country. Participate in events and campaigns held at PokÃ©mon movie theaters, PokÃ©mon card game stores, etc. nationwide, collect various cards, and enjoy your collection to the fullest! The PokÃ©mon differ depending on where you get the card, and the illustrations and moves are original to the PokÃ©mon card game “Collection Challenge”, so it’s truly a valuable card that can only be obtained here!!”

1999 Base Set - Unlimited - Venusaur 15/102 - HoloAbout #Venusaur 15/102 from the PokÃ©mon Base Set holds a significant place in the history of the PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game. Released in North America on January 9, 1999, by Wizards of the Coast, the Base Set was the first English-language set of PokÃ©mon cards, adapted from the Japanese PokÃ©mon Card Game launched by Media Factory in 1996. The Base Set introduced players to the original 151 PokÃ©mon from the PokÃ©mon Red and Blue video games, with Venusaur 15/102 being one of the setâ€™s flagship holographic (holo) cards. Venusaur, alongside Charizard and Blastoise, forms the “Big 3” of the Base Setâ€”three iconic Stage 2 PokÃ©mon that became the most coveted cards due to their rarity, power, and cultural significance. These cards represent the final evolutions of the starter PokÃ©mon from the PokÃ©mon Red and Blue games (Bulbasaur, Charmander, and Squirtle), resonating deeply with fans of the franchise. The Unlimited print, while not as scarce as First Edition, was still highly sought after due to its holographic shine and the nostalgia tied to the early PokÃ©mon craze of the late 1990s.

Dragonite FB (018/DPt-P) Beat of the Frontier Release Commemoration Tournament PrizeAbout #The 2009 Beat of the Frontier Release Commemoration Tournament, part of the PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game (TCG) Challenge Hiroba events in Japan, was held to celebrate the release of the Beat of the Frontier expansion (released in English as Supreme Victors) on March 6, 2009. These events were designed to promote the PokÃ©mon TCG by hosting tournaments in large public venues like shopping malls and department stores, increasing accessibility and awareness compared to the more traditional PokÃ©mon Card Gym events held in hobby shops.
Participation and performance in the tournaments were rewarded with exclusive promotional cards
â€¢	Participation Prize: All participants received a SP Energy card (cosmos holofoil). Some locations also distributed a Pikachu cosmos holofoil card, which had previously been awarded at the Battle Road 2008 events. This was likely due to leftover stock from the prematurely canceled Battle Road 2008.
â€¢	One Win: Players who won at least one match received a Battle Tower card (cosmos holofoil, DPt-P Promotional print) stamped with the Beat of the Frontier expansion logo on the bottom right of the illustration. This card was part of the Supreme Victors expansion in English.
â€¢	Two Wins: Players achieving two wins were awarded a Dragonite FB (Frontier Brainâ€™s) card (cosmos holofoil, DPt-P Promotional print), also stamped with the Beat of the Frontier expansion logo. This card was a notable prize for its rarity and connection to the Frontier Brains theme.
â€¢	Winner: Winners of the tournament would receive a Drifblim card, also stamped with the setâ€™s logo.

Cresselia (020/L-P) Super Rank PrizeAbout #The Cresselia 020/L-P Japanese Promo is a rare and highly sought-after PokÃ©mon card released exclusively through the PokÃ©mon Daisuki Club in Japan.
Established in January 2004, the PokÃ©mon Daisuki Club was a Japanese fan club for PokÃ©mon enthusiasts, covering the video games, anime, and Trading Card Game (TCG). It required an annual membership fee and a Japanese address for registration. Members received a membership card and could earn Action Points (AP) by participating in events, tournaments, contests, surveys, and other activities. Members accumulated “AP” to achieve ranks, with higher ranks unlocking exclusive promotional cards.
The card was Awarded to members who reached “Super Rank” by accumulating 3,200 AP. This was the highest rank in 2008 and remained a significant milestone in 2009 and beyond. The card was part of a set with Darkrai 021/L-P, given together to Super Rank members starting in 2009. The sealed packet also included cosmos holofoil Psychic and Dark Basic Energy cards from the 2009 Gym Challenge events.

While going through my old console collection one day, I came across a metal carry case featuring Rayquaza thatâ€™s just the right size to fit a Game Boy Advance SP inside.
After searching online, I couldnâ€™t find much about it, just a few eBay listings but no one seemed to really know anything about it. I submitted a post on elitefourum.com and continued my research, but ultimately hit a dead end.
Now a Collectible #More recently, in 2025, this item has become something of a collectible. More and more collectors are searching for information about it, and while more are appearing on the secondhand market, the travel case remained a mystery. Knowledge of its existence has primarily circulated through online forums, Reddit threads, and collector groups often accompanied by vague recollections.
Personal Research #As someone who personally owned this case, I recall purchasing it as part of a PokÃ©mon Emerald bundle from a Toys â€œRâ€ Us store in the UK. However, unlike what I had heard from others, I donâ€™t remember purchasing a Game Boy Advance SP with it, I already owned one and just purchased the game.
Using Archive.orgâ€™s Wayback Machine, I searched archived versions of the UK Toys â€œRâ€ Us website from around the gameâ€™s release. After combing through dozens of captures, I still couldnâ€™t find any promotional material on their homepage, so I switched to a more in-depth search of their product pages. Finally, I found it.
Screenshot from archive.org - Jan-03-2006Though the image quality was poor, this confirmed what my memory had preserved: this case was a Toys â€œRâ€ Us exclusive.
The listing reads:
GBA PokÃ©mon Emerald
Long-awaited PokÃ©mon Emerald plus exclusive Travel Case.
Unfortunately, the actual listing itself has not been archived, and I still havenâ€™t managed to find any additional information. However, I do remember there being promotional material in-store at Toys â€œRâ€ Us at the time, so hopefully more will surface in the future.
Details of the Case #Hereâ€™s what is known about the case:
Material: Metal shell Design: Custom-molded to snugly fit a GBA SP. Strap: Green nylon/fabric strap Availability: Bundled with PokÃ©mon Emerald at Toys â€œRâ€ Us UK stores (and possibly through their website). Era: Released alongside the European release of PokÃ©mon Emerald around October 21, 2005. Sold out by 2006 Inside: Contains two grey foam inserts (top and bottom) for padding; lined with smooth black fabric Conclusion #The Rayquaza Game Boy Advance SP travel case serves as a reminder of a time when gaming accessories were more regionally unique and often fleeting in availability. While it may not have the recognition of limited-edition consoles or tournament prizes, its rarity and connection to one of the most beloved PokÃ©mon titles give it a unique place in collecting history.
Thanks to tools like Archive.org and the dedication of nostalgic fans, small fragments of gaming history like this continue to be uncovered and appreciated. If you happen to own one, consider yourself lucky, you hold a piece of forgotten PokÃ©mon memorabilia that many are still searching for more information about.
Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Letâ€™s chat about it.

title: PokÃ©mon Emerald Rayquaza Metal GBA SP Case

content:
The Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit (featuring Manaphy and Lucario) was released in the Diamond & Pearl era, but some versions of these kits were known to include booster packs from late EX-series sets. These late EX-series packs were produced before the full transition into the Diamond & Pearl sets and can be a significant treat for collectors, as they tend to be harder to find today.
Likely Booster Packs Included: #The contents of the Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit varied over time and across different print runs, but here are the key booster packs you might find:
Diamond & Pearl Base Set Most common pack to be included, as this is the core set of the Diamond & Pearl era.
Mysterious Treasures Second most common pack to appear, also from the Diamond & Pearl block, and highly sought after by players due to the unique cards it includes (like Electivire and Mew).
Secret Wonders A slightly rarer pack that introduces several beloved cards and mechanics from the Diamond & Pearl era.
Great Encounters Another set from the Diamond & Pearl era, notable for powerful cards like Garchomp and Lugia.
Majestic Dawn Less common in packs but still a possibility, known for powerful Legendary PokÃ©mon and cards like Dialga and Palkia.
Late EX Series Packs: #Beyond the Diamond & Pearl sets, some Trainer Kits were reported to contain booster packs from the later EX-series, particularly from 2005â€“2007. These were part of the tail end of the EX era, and getting one of these packs adds significant rarity and potential value to the Trainer Kit. The most notable packs include:
EX Holon Phantoms Rarity: Relatively rare but occasionally included in later print runs of the Trainer Kits.
EX Power Keepers Rarity: Sometimes included in Trainer Kits, though less frequently than Holon Phantoms.
EX Legend Maker Rarity: Less common, but still possible to find in Trainer Kits.
EX Deoxys Rarity: Very rare in the Trainer Kit, but certainly possible.
Likely Pack Combinations: #The most common packs will still be from the Diamond & Pearl era, as those were the sets in active circulation when the Trainer Kits were released.
EX-series packs are considered rarer, but can sometimes be found so itâ€™s more of a special bonus for those lucky enough to find one.
The following breakdown is not official, just what we can assume from current data available.
Rarity Breakdown: Diamond & Pearl Base Set â€“ ~50% chance (most common)
Mysterious Treasures â€“ ~20-25% chance
Secret Wonders â€“ ~15-20% chance
Great Encounters â€“ ~10-15% chance
Majestic Dawn â€“ ~5-10% chance
EX Holon Phantoms â€“ ~5% chance (rarer)
EX Power Keepers â€“ ~5% chance (rarer)
EX Legend Maker / EX Deoxys â€“ <5% chance (very rare)
Conclusion: #The Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit is primarily designed around the Diamond & Pearl series, but itâ€™s certainly possible to find late EX-series packs mixed in, particularly in certain batches of the product. These packs are more rare, but they add an exciting element for collectors hunting for EX-era cards.
If you’re hoping for a specific set like EX, your odds are fairly low, but the possibility certainly exists!
Let’s test! #I decided to purchase a Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit from eBay. Snagged one from an auction for only
When the package arrived, I carefully inspected the sealed product, scanning for any signs of wear or tampering. I wanted to ensure I wasnâ€™t about to open something that had been messed with.
Whilst inspecting, I noticed that the edge of the booster pack was visible through the side of the plastic. The light hit it just right, and I could make out enough of the artwork to start formulating a guess about which set it could be from.
After a closer look at the booster packâ€™s art, I began comparing it with the different pack arts from all the sets we previously covered what it could be. There are a lot of possibilities, and I ended up thinking the pack featured Kabutops, The colors and design seemed to line up, and I grew confident that I had an EX Holon Phantoms pack in my hands.
I decided to open the kit and record it for fun, sort of like a booster pack opening! You can watch the full opening on my YouTube:
Unwrapping the kit, I was greeted with a surprise: it wasnâ€™t Kabutops after all. Instead, the pack featured Zangoose!
Though I had been wrong about the pack art, I wasnâ€™t disappointed in the slightest! It was still an EX Holon Phantoms pack like i had hoped for, and it felt like a stroke of luck that Iâ€™d pulled a pack from this sought-after set. In the end, my guess had been close enough, and it was a fun experience learning about this product.
Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Letâ€™s chat about it.

content:
What is the Black Flame Ninetales?
If you asked that question to an AI today, you might get a response like the one ChatGPT gave me here:
The oldest cited source, and the first image used in many of those responses, comes from a post I made on EliteFourum (formerly elitefourum.proboards.com) all the way back in October 2020.
I was intrigued after spotting a version of Base Set Ninetales in the wild that looked noticeably different. At the time, there was barely any information about it online, so I dug deeper and decided to create a post documenting the card on EliteFourum. That post gained significant attention within the collecting community. Some collectors had already noticed the variant and had been quietly acquiring them for years.
The new information I shared prompted more collectors to come forward with additional research and insights into this mysterious card. Eventually, this community effort led to collectors formally requesting that the grading company CGC recognize the variant using my article as a key reference point.
Thanks to the support of the collectors at EliteFourum and the research I contributed, CGC officially recognized the card as a variant on February 9th, 2021. They even published their own article on the subject, which you can read here:
ğŸ‘‰ CGC article on the Black Flame Ninetales
Since then the card has become more recognized in the community as well as other leading grading companies have officially recognized the variant too like PSA.
Iâ€™m incredibly proud to have made a lasting impact on the PokÃ©mon TCG community and grateful to the fellow collectors at EliteFourum who helped along the way.
Below is a copy of the original article I wrote five years ago. For more discussion and collector insights, I highly recommend checking out the original thread here:
ğŸ”— The Black Flame Ninetales â€“ EliteFourum
Original Article (October 2020) #The Black Flame Ninetales #For those that are seeing this for the first time itâ€™s an Unlimited Base Set Ninetales (12/102) but the flame around Ninetales is black instead of purple.
(See side by side comparison below)
After searching ebay for a few monthâ€™s checking every Ninetales card listed i managed to find one on a BIN and scooped it up, Having it in hand i was now determined to find out some more information about it starting with evidence of it being pulled from a pack.
It took a while searching through pack opening videos for every time a Ninetales was pulled but i finally found one being pulled from 6 years a go!
PrimetimePokemonâ€™s Pull (Timestamp: 10:52)See also LeonHartâ€™s pack opening video found by @jkanly
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q0MU7sAmMVY
You can see in these videoâ€™s that the Booster Packs being opened are;
Identifying Shadowless & Unlimited Base set Boxes & Packs
Made in the U.S.A., â€œ1999-2000â€ copywrites, Short seal pack: There is no evidence this card comes from any other pack as of yet.
Error or Variant? #My initial theory was that itâ€™s an error card since the packs it comes from are a late print of Unlimited but the Black Flame is not present on previous print runs of Unlimited, leading me to speculate that it was a possible printing error.
However keep in mind that a 1999-2000 Base Set Booster Pack is not guaranteed to have a 1999-2000 print Holo card inside, it has been rumoured that the non-2000 print holoâ€™s inside the packs are old stock, Possibly from an early print run of Unlimited. This would make the most sense as the Black Flame Ninetales shares itâ€™s black flame with the Shadowless & 1st Edition versions and it is also not a 1999-2000 print holo.
Additional Information #The black flame is also clearly visible on all 1st Edition, Shadowless, Japanese Base Set & Evolutions Ninetales as well. These are the only other prints that contain the black flame that i have found. All other Languages of Unlimited Base Set as well as the 1999-2000 Print, Base Set 2 & Legendary Collection Ninetales have the purple flame.
I would still love to find out more about this card. If you know any more information about it or have some theories please share! There is still a ton i donâ€™t know but i am grateful for the efour community teaching me new things daily so please let me know if anything is wrong & i will correct it. Finally i encourage you to check through your binders to see if you have one of these super rare Ninetales and share it below ğŸ˜„
Thanks to: #@alovell â€“ for sharing his thread were he found one of these errorâ€™s. @jkanly â€“ for his brilliant guide helping me determine which packs the error comes from.
